title: 108_hr875
content: The Act may be cited as the "Over-the-Road Bus Security and Safety Act of 2003" and provides emergency security assistance for over-the-road buses. The Over-the-Road Bus Security and Safety Act of 2003 establishes a grant program for private bus operators to improve security, including constructing secure facilities, protecting drivers, upgrading equipment for passenger information, and training employees in security procedures. The Over-the-Road Bus Security and Safety Act of 2003 establishes a grant program for private bus operators to improve security, including procedures, hiring security officers, installing surveillance equipment, employee background checks, emergency communication systems, and passenger screening programs. Grants can be used to reimburse operators for security-related costs incurred since September 11, 2001. The Federal share of the cost for grants under the Over-the-Road Bus Security and Safety Act of 2003 is 90 percent. The Secretary must consider private bus operators who have enhanced security measures since September 11, 2001. Grants are subject to terms and conditions outlined in the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century. The Secretary must approve a security improvement plan before granting funds to private over-the-road bus operators. Applicants must coordinate security improvements with terminal owners. The definition of over-the-road bus is provided in section 4. SEC. 4 defines an over-the-road bus as having an elevated passenger deck over a baggage compartment. SEC. 5 requires bus operators to have a security assessment approved before receiving funds. The Secretary of Transportation must submit a preliminary report to the Senate and House committees within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will assess the over-the-road bus security grant program, actions taken to address security issues, and the need for additional legislation to ensure the security of travelers on over-the-road buses. The Secretary of Transportation is required to assess the security of Americans traveling on over-the-road buses, including economic impacts, research needs, and industry best practices. Consultation with industry, labor, and other groups is mandated for this assessment. SEC. 6. FUNDING. $99,000,000 authorized for Secretary of Transportation for fiscal years 2003 and 2004. Sums available until expended.
